s1: A practically oriented introduction to programming paradigms for parallel computers.
s2: This course is an introduction to relational databases and the general skills for designing and using them.

s1: Considers definitions of program efficiency on parallel computers, addresses the modelling, analysis and measurement of program performance.
s2: Apply database design methods on functional dependencies and normal forms to evaluate the quality of a relational database design.

s1: Description, implementation and use of parallel programming languages, parallel features of operating systems, library routines and applications.
s2: The topics include the relational data model, SQL, entity-relationship model, functional dependencies, (de-)normalisation, relational algebra, query processing and optimisation, database transactions and security.

s1: Be proficient at programming multiple parallel machines in more than one special programming language or programming system.
s2: Apply database design methods on functional dependencies and normal forms to evaluate the quality of a relational database design.

s1: Be able to descriptively compare the performance of different programs and methods on one machine
s2: Apply database design methods on functional dependencies and normal forms to evaluate the quality of a relational database design.

s1: Demonstrate advanced knowledge of the elements of parallel programming language and system implementation.
s2: Apply database design methods on functional dependencies and normal forms to evaluate the quality of a relational database design.

s1: Recall the history of parallel systems and describe the developments in the field.
s2: Describe the basic concepts of the relational model and understand its mathematical foundation;
